Recap: A surprise birthday party is thrown for Coop and although the family thinks that one of the other's planned it for him, it turns out that it was Lizzie. Coop and Ava are upset at first, but Lizzie claims that she planned it while they were still together. Lizzie looks at it as her last chance to get Coop back. She locks Ava away after telling her about she and Coop sleeping together and tries to get back with Coop. He reminds her that things are done but she convinces him to have one last dance with her. Ava escapes and pushes Lizzie's face into the birthday cake. Lizzie calls her mom to complain and when she mentions her recent nausea at the thought of Coop and Ava, Beth says not to mention that word because of her morning sickness. It dawns on Lizzie that she may be pregnant and she takes a test just as Alan shows up to tell her that he is going to sue the Coopers for the way that they treated her. She convinces him to leave before he finds the test. Once he leaves though Buzz shows up to try and convince Lizzie that he knows that there is still a good person inside of her and then Coop shows up and takes her to the cemetery to her Dad's grave. He tells her that at the party she acted just like Phillip and could have hurt Ava to get what she wanted and tells her that she needs to move on. She finds out that she is pregnant and although is very upset about it at first, a talk with Lillian helps her to see that children can be a positive thing in their parent's lives. She goes to the cemetery to talk with her father and tells him that she wishes he were there because although he wouldn't be happy with her she knows he would be behind her.
Transcript: Lizzie: Am I getting fat? Oh, my gosh, tell me that I'm not. I need to look perfect for Coop tonight. Being away from him is actually ruining my complexion. God, I'm tired all the time. I can't eat. This is the last chance I have to make Coop love me again.

Lizzie: Happy with you?
Ava: Who knows, maybe. We'll see.

Ava: You are such a liar.
Lizzie: You wish. Go ask him. We both had a night that we will never forget.
Ava: Coop and I weren't even seeing each other then. And if he wanted to do that, then that was his business.

Coop: Lizzie, we don't belong together. All right, we tried. It was a lot more work than it supposed to be. We just need to meet other people.

Coop: I did, all right? I do love you, Lizzie, but just not the way you want me to.
Lizzie: I know, I know. Okay? You keep saying that. I just wanted to do something nice for you before we ended it officially.
Coop: ( Sighs ) Thank you, really. But you just need to stop. Enough. All right? Now, look, have you seen Ava anywhere?

Beth: Okay, you're right. You're right. But first let's go home and we'll get something to eat.

Alan: Elizabeth?
Lizzie: Granddad, what horrible timing. Okay, do not even breathe in the direction of the bathroom.
Alan: Why didn't you open the door? Is something wrong?

Alan: Elizabeth, you don't have to hide anything. Your mother told me everything.
Lizzie: She did.
Alan: Now, you have to remember when you get involved with a Cooper, it turns into being a disaster.
Lizzie: Yes, it was. It was terrible.
Alan: Terrible? It was a crime. I mean, you paid for this boy's party that you threw, then they had you arrested. I mean, I'm thinking about a lawsuit.
Lizzie: No, Granddad, it is okay.
Alan: No, it is not okay.
Lizzie: You know why, because I'm not going to let the Coopers break my spirit. I am a Spaulding and it's about time people starting treating me like one.
Alan: That's the way I like to hear you talk, Elizabeth. Very special. ( Alarm ringing ) What is that?
Lizzie: That's my alarm clock. Yeah, it's broken.
Alan: Are you cooking something?

Lizzie: Yeah, right. It just keeps going off. But you know what, maybe it's a sign.. maybe it's a sign that it's about time for me to start standing on my two feet and taking care of my own problems. I learned that from you. And I love you so much. Yeah, I do. Okay, bye.
Alan: Wha...
Lizzie: ( Sighs ) ( knock on the door ) What... Buzz, what are you doing here?
Buzz: Hi. Can about we talk?
Lizzie: Maybe tomorrow...
Buzz: How about today?
Lizzie: Okay, how did I know that you were going to say that?

Buzz: Listen, I cannot understand all of the things you do, but I've got a soft spot for you, I'm rooting for you. There is a lot of good in you, but it just hasn't found it's way out yet. It hasn't learned yet. You and Coop, if it worked out differently, if you timed it differently, maybe later on it would have worked out.
Lizzie: Why are you being nice to me?
Buzz: Because I've known you since you were a little girl. I watched you grow up. I watched you fight leukemia. You're a strong, strong lady.
Lizzie: That's the second time I heard that tonight.

Buzz: Well, maybe it's because you are. Look, you know, some people remember you because of your bad behavior. But you know why I remember you. I remember a girl who gave me my restaurant back, a girl who fought her whole family to fit in with mine. You made a mistake. So, you made mistakes. So, I don't think you should be alone tonight.
Lizzie: That is so sweet, Buzz. But you know something, I am not alone. I have Roxy. Yeah.
Buzz: I'll tell you what, I'll drop you off at Lillian's or your mom's. Can I use your bathroom because I got some frosting on my pants.
Lizzie: No, if you have frosting on your pants, that is your own fault.
Buzz: No, actually, it's yours.

Lizzie: So, you just come here to tell me I've ruined Coop's whole birthday party? Yeah, okay, where are they? Where are the rest of the Lizzie lynchers. Come on, Coopers, come out, get out before I sic Roxy on you. Yeha, get out.
Buzz: You know, you should talk to someone.
Lizzie: Okay, out! ( Sighs ) ( knock on the door ) What is going on? What do you... hi. No, I don't want to see anyone.
Coop: Look, we're not. We're going to be alone.
Lizzie: ( Sighs ) Okay.
Lizzie: I thought when you said you wanted to be alone, that... no way. Why are we here? Is this some kind of cruel joke, because it isn't funny.
Coop: No, Lizzie, I'm not trying to hurt you. I just needed to bring you someplace so you would listen.
Lizzie: You brought me here...
Coop: To talk. All we're doing is talking.

Lizzie: When my dad tried to kidnap me, you saved me. And when he was killed and I was grieving, you stood beside me. When I found out that it was my granddad that did it, you helped me through it. You have been the only good thing in my entire life, and now you are going to dump me here, outside my dad's tomb?

Coop: Lizzie, I am not dumping you, okay? I'm trying to get through to you. I am just worried about you. Do you remember when your dad was falling apart? You were so hurt because you wanted to help him and he wouldn't let you.
Lizzie: Oh, okay, so I need help right now. Psycho Lizzie. I'm just psycho...
Coop: Would you stop. Just stop it.
Lizzie: It's in my genes, isn't it? It's just a matter of time before I go off?
Coop: You don't have to go off, though, Lizzie.
Lizzie: No. No, I could see some more therapists, I could maybe go to another camp for freaks. I thought you were different. I thought you believed in me.
Coop: I do. I do believe in you, Lizzie, but you need to step back and you need to take a look at yourself. What you did tonight, Ava could have seriously been hurt.
Lizzie: Oh, Ava, Ava, Ava. Ava is the only thing that you care about.

Coop: Oh, damn it, Lizzie, that is not true. You scared me tonight. And you know what, and I think you scared yourself. Lizzie, you rigged that elevator. You pushed Ava into it. It's like you took somebody and you made them hostage. That's something you can go to jail for. That is something that your dad would have done.
Lizzie: No, it wasn't like that.
Coop: You were hurt because your father did what he wanted to do without any regard for anyone else. And you know what, that's exactly how you acted tonight. And you are better than that, Lizzie.
Lizzie: You made me better than that. Without you, I will become just like the rest of my family.
Coop: No, no. It is a choice. But you can make the right one. Lizzie, you have overcome so much. I mean, you can get over us.
Lizzie: What if I can't? What if everything is ruined forever?
Coop: No, no. Guilt will not work here, all right? I've seen you play that card 100 different times, right? Look who you're talking to. It's me, Lizzie. It's Coop.
Lizzie: So why do you think... why do you think you don't love me anymore? You can love me, love me.

Coop: Look, I wanted to. I really wanted it to work. Look, did you ever think that maybe we were meant to meet each other right now because maybe I was meant to be the guy that would help you come out from underneath this power, this control that your family had over you.
Lizzie: Oh, great. So, what, I was a project, and now your work here is done?

Coop: Lizzie... look, look at me. Someday in the not so distant future you are going to meet a man who is going to love you the way you deserved to be loved, the way Lizzie wants to be loved. And then you know what, you're going to forget all about me.
Lizzie: No, no, I won't. I can't.
Coop: Lizzie. I'm not him. I'm not that guy.

Lizzie: (Sobbing ) Coop is gone. I had so many stupid dreams for us-- getting married, living in granddad's mansion, driving matching sports cars, which we would have traded in for a minivan as soon as... oh, my gosh, okay. Okay, Roxy, stay here and keep your toes crossed. Okay, well, the box says that if I'm pregnant, the stick will turn blue. It's kind of hard to tell in this light. I left this one in too long because it was... it was a really long time. I just... I need to try it again, yeah. How can this be? I can't even take care of myself. What am I going to do with a baby? Sometimes I'm not even sure if I fed you. ( Sighs ) No, I can't be a mom. I'm too young. I don't have the wardrobe.
Man: Miss, are you okay?
Lizzie: It's just a stomachache. I'm not... I'm not.
Lillian: Lizzie? What a wonderful surprise. Sweetheart. Honey, what is it? What's the matter?

Lizzie: Nana, I don't know what's wrong with me. I screw everything up. I'm trying so hard. And it's going okay for a while, and then I just... I blow everything up. It's like my entire life it is me verses me.
Lillian: Sweetie, we all feel like that sometimes. I mean, especially after we made a mistake, or something.
Lizzie: I am a big mistake.
Lillian: You are not. Now, you come and tell me what happened?

Lizzie: I was born, that's what happened. Look at me, I have never been normal. I shot someone when I was supposed to be playing with dolls. Of course I can't keep a guy. I mean, bullet-proof vests are so last year.
Lillian: I take it this is about Coop.
Lizzie: It's about everything. I can't get a break.

Lillian: Oh, sweetheart, sweetie. Oh, how I wish I could tell you it's going to get easier, but life is so full of challenges. And that's why you're so lucky that you're such a strong, resilient young woman.
Lizzie: You're the strong one. I have no idea how you did it, how you've been through everything that you've been through.
Lillian: Believe me, at your age I was not strong. I had to learn from my mistakes. And let me tell you, and your mother helped a lot.
Lizzie: How does that make a difference?

Lillian: Well, I had to be strong. I decided I had to be strong and protect my daughter. And protecting Beth became my life's work. Of course, I realized I couldn't take care of all her problems. She had to face them on her own. You know what helped her?
Lizzie: Sedatives?
Lillian: No. Lizzie, you.
Lizzie: So, the meaning of life, it's being a mom?
Lillian: No, no, not at all, honey. It's just that when you're a mom, you love someone more than you love yourself. You put someone ahead of you.
Lizzie: But you and mom were all alone, and me and mom were alone when dad left us in Arizona. And having a baby, and doing that all by yourself, that's really hard. Didn't you just want to run away?
Lillian: Never. And that's why I know that you're going to be okay.
Lizzie: You know. You can tell.

Lillian: I know that we're survivors, Lizzie. And things are calming down right now. I mean, your grandfather's home, your mother and your grandfather are having a baby, which we know is not perfect, is it? But something wonderful is going to come out of that. You're going to have a little baby brother or sister. You know, having a baby is such a wonderful event, and it shows you things are turning around. So you just have to hang in there.
Lizzie: Hang in?

Lillian: Yes. I want you to have faith in yourself. I want you to realized how loved you are. You know, when you and James were born, you brought so much joy into this family. You really did. Having a baby is just a wonderful event. Why are you here?
Lizzie: I... it was a stomachache.
Lillian: Do you want me to call Mel to examine...
Lizzie: No. It's... it's not that bad anymore. I love you, Nana. Talking to you made me feel better.
